positive.review:
As most Persona fans know, the global launch of this game did have a shaky start with unbalanced rewards, scheduling, communication, etc. However, there's been slight improvements all around the board and it does enough to make the game feel fun and rewarding even for F2P! I've never been tempted to spend money and it's completely unnecessary unless you are chasing the top of the ranked leaderboards. An engaging story, frequent new events/characters, unique gameplay, an S tier soundtrack, strong community presence, and more, brings just the right balance of grinding and relaxing with what you already have. The only times the game has ever felt a little too pressured for grinding is certain story events that have 10-20 chapters and can be a slog, otherwise this is the best gacha I've seen to make grinding very rewarding and not frustrating. You can play for 5 minutes a day to get literally all the rewards aside from occasionally spending a few more minutes to do a limited time event. While I enjoy Persona games, it's difficult to find the right balance between daily life, story, and grinding. In P5X you have more freedom to choose to pay more attention to any 1 mechanic and you don't feel punished or that you've 'ruined' a run because there's no time limit. While I'm not a fan of turn based combat, it is very easy to get into with this game and then there's plenty of room to improve and expand your knowledge of the in game systems at your own pace. 
There's a few problems mentioning unfortunately. The only gripe I have with mastering the combat system, would be that a lot of keywords and values are sometimes used in multiple ways and trying to find info on a wiki is extremely difficult. These especially happens with the Metro of Desire (rouguelite?) gamemode that I find very fun, but there are so many specific interactions that are hard to figure out without a better wiki online or in game. Also, the multiplayer features are very fun but I feel they should be expanded on, as this game is a unique opportunity to have a more social gameplay side to Persona. As always, games like this can have strange quirks that are morally gray because it's standard for anime. It's not that bad in this game compared to most forms of similar media, but it is a set back and needs to be worked on in the future. This includes the ages of certain characters being strange for how they are presented. They act as an adult, look the same or older than most college students, sometimes have options for very adult outfits, but they are 16 in the story instead of 18+. You can 'date' most female characters but not any male characters. Very weird...
I will probably always be F2P in this game unless it gets a lot better, but I easily would've preferred a $20-30 price tag and then to have the game be more modeled around no microtransactions. I know this would change how content would be released and it might be difficult to keep going after a couple years, but I think it's worth looking into compromises when developing these types of games.

Overall, the game is a 7/10. If you really like Persona, you should at least try it since it's free. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys turn-based combat, a fun story with likable characters, JRPGs, Gacha, Persona, amazing soundtracks, and maybe even MMO if it's for the community aspect rather than combat. With some improvements to the clarity of certain math and interactions in the game, more gamemodes/features to use with friends, less crunch/frustration from occasional story events (the smallest issue), and moving away from some of the strange tropes in most anime media, the game seems to have the potential to be a 9/10.

P5X is a gatcha game, but you do not need to spend money on it. If you want, look up a guide on how to do multiple guest accounts on your phone to do the first 50 or more pulls. Once you have a 5 star or two you want, "lock in" the guest account by linking it to your google account or similar. afterward, login here and play as you like.

Beyond that strategy, the game is fairly generous with meta jewels (the primary resource for gatcha pulls). With a tiny bit of luck and using your stamina every day, its not hard to get a team together that can handle all of the story content and even most of the level 80 challenges. 

As for the story, the first palace kinda sucks. It has a stupid story that is basically a weak version of P5's first palace. Atlus copied their own homework but worse on this one. After that, the second and third palaces (the only two out at time of review) are great. In my opinion, the story and puzzles of the third P5X palace rivals some of the P5 palaces. If they continue like this, the rest of them should be fire.

Finally, the soundtrack is amazing...I know. Shocking coming from an Atlus game.

This is a “gacha” game, which is free to play but charges real money to get in game items.  The things to buy are shortcuts for advancing your character’s many statistics, such as weapon strength, character level, persona level, revelation card level, etc.   There are also shortcuts to buy things that increase your odds of getting a character you want.   You’re guaranteed to get a “5-star” item within 80 pulls, but often you end up with a character you already have, and not the character you really want.

I’ve resisted the siren call of these shortcuts and despite this, I’ve made it pretty far in the game.  In fact, I’m all caught up on the story and am just waiting for the publisher to release the next chapter.  My main party is leveled up, but the more ancillary characters are not.  It would be nice to upgrade everyone and everything quickly, but I’m content with proceeding at a slower pace without spending any money.

The game feels very much so like a proper addition to the series' mainline games. It has good original characters, a solid story (even though it feels a bit lackluster compared to other mainline titles) and could serve as a decent free-to-play introduction for people who are curious about the series but not to the point of spending money to find out; that is if the person has a good tolerance for gacha and microtransactions, but if they are like me who like their gachas, they (maybe) won't be disappointed since the game is generous enough with multiple character selectors and a pity system just like other gachas and all Hoyoverse games to the point that it's perfectly feasible to be free-to-play and still consistenly getting almost every featured new character from the banners.
As I said, it feels like a proper addition to the series, but it does utilize a lot (and I mean a LOT) of aspects and gameplay mechanics from the original Persona 5. It literally features the same in-game locations, with the exception being the main characters' school and maybe a few new locations like the beach (which was only available during the summer event). Aside from that, if you're a fan of Persona 5, it is neat to see that world and familiar locations through the eyes of an entirely new cast of main characters.
That being said, I am very biased due to Persona being my favorite video game series by far; so take my review with maybe a few pounds of salt.

TL;DR: Too much Persona 5 is pretty much welcome in my book; good characters and story; generous enough rewards and gacha mechanics so you can pretty much ignore it and focus on the main story if you like; a great free way to try the series if you're new to it and finding out if you want to play the other games or not.

Persona 5 Royal is a finished artistic masterpiece.
Persona 5 The Phantom X is Persona 5 Royal's free demo with optional donations to devs:
- Quick daily missions
- Stamina system for short auto battle sessions
- Touchscreen-friendly UI (30GB for phone)

Many people criticize it as a monetization engine, similar to Genshin Impact and Infinity Nikki.

According to Reddit, it costs $1k-$2k to get 7 copies of a 5★ character.
The Platinum Pass is $14.99, giving you 10 Platinum Tickets + other goodies.
The Monthly Platinum Set (for more Platinum Tickets) is $32.99.

The game can be played free, if you do 15-30 minutes daily missions and endless grinding, while ignoring all the in-game pressure systems push players toward spending (or gambling).

The real product for sale is not the actual game, but to fulfill your desire, completionism, fear of missing out, attachment to characters and nostalgia for Persona 5. 

It gives Persona fans the “taste” of Persona 5 Royal:
Same visual style / aesthetic (UI, animations, background music, the vibe)
Same combat feel (turn-based, weakness-exploiting, 1-more style combat)
Same Metaverse concept (general tone, structure and feel)
Same story structure (metaverse corruption → target → dungeon → change of heart loop)
Same Phantom Thief fantasy (a small group of friends' school life, social interactions and bonding)

Yet it's nothing compared to Persona 5 Royal:
Narrative - weaker depth
Story and characters - less emotional and storytelling
Weekly events with rotating FOMO banners
Daily mission meaning more grinding
Paid bundles with regional reward differences

From business perspective, this makes perfect sense.
Fans love the Art style, Character, Story, Combat system of the Persona 3 → 5 Royal. 
With 27 million+ copies sold, tht's a ready-made audience that is highly likely to engage with anything Persona-related. 
Plus Persona 5 is a strong brand, so even casual players or mobile players who never played it before can quickly recognize the title - additional potential player base - the leverage is massive. 
So why not pouring money into a cash cow like this one, dear investors?
This game can reach millions of phone users, and those who never tried Persona PC games but interested to get a feel of it for free.
Pay as you wish later on...slowly drain your wallets. 
What a brilliant idea!

Rather than a rehash of P5 (Royal), they (re)placed new characters into a similar universe; or perhaps replaced them? The original P5 characters are available, but are mainly used in one of the side stories; an actual rehash of P5.

Persona5: The Phantom X is what happens when Atlus looked at Persona 5 and said:
“Yup, we can absolutely turn this into a mobile game that devours your free time *and* your willpower.”

You’re a new Phantom Thief (canon name Nagisa / Wonder) with a talking owl roommate, still going to school by day and committing stylish metaphysical crimes by night… except now your greatest enemy isn’t a god, it’s the **energy system**.

---

### Pros:

* It’s literally Persona 5 again, but on PC & mobile and somehow still stupidly stylish: bold UI, banger music, turn-based combat with “1 More” and All-Out Attacks.
* Full social-sim + dungeon crawl combo: hang out in Tokyo, raise stats, bond with people, then dive into Mementos and Palaces in the Metaverse to beat up their trauma.
* Gacha lets you pull cognitive versions of confidants as units. Truly the most efficient way to turn friendship into DPS.
* Wonder + Lufel (owl buddy) are actually likable, and the new cast feels like someone asked, “What if we made another Phantom Thieves but with extra drip?”
* It’s free-to-play, and early on the game yeets so many rewards at you that you start thinking, “Maybe gacha isn’t so bad actually” (this is a trap).

---

### Cons:

* No calendar system—your life is now ruled by **stamina bars**. Want to study OR grind a dungeon? Pick one, line up behind the energy timer like it’s a grocery store.
* Party is strong, story is solid, but you will occasionally remember this is technically a phone game when 17 menus pop up asking you to collect mail, rewards, points, and your dignity.
* Some bosses are emotionally impactful, others are “Subway Slammer” levels of meme villainy, making it hard to stay serious when a guy basically yells “The whole train is mine for slammin’!”
* Auto-battle exists, so you’ll catch yourself letting the game play itself while you just sit there like a manager on salary.

---

### Peak Phantom X Moments:

* Boot game “just to grab login rewards,” emerge 2 hours later having cleared 3 floors of Mementos, 10 side quests, and exactly 0 real-life responsibilities.
* Burning through all your stamina on grinding, then realizing you still haven’t progressed the actual story and Wonder is still failing school.
* Landing your 10-pull: nine dudes you don’t care about and one insanely cracked unit that now defines your whole personality.
* Reading a long, emotional Velvet Room monologue… while also mentally calculating if you’ll have enough energy left to farm materials after.

---

9/10

Persona 5 X is a game I was looking forward to since it's original announcement. I've been holding my tongue waiting to see how the game would pan out before giving my thoughts positive or negative, but I think I'm ready now after this third palace has been completed.

For context, I'm a huge fan of ATLUS titles like SMT, Metaphor and of course Persona. I've played several titles across their catalog and always look forward to the next. 

Story - The first palace of the game while poorly written I had no issues excusing because it was so bad I ended up laughing and enjoying myself the entire way through. The villain is ridiculous both in and outside of the metaverse which is different to the original P5 as the metaverse was where their worst traits would go out of control. The second palace unfortunately has no redeeming qualities and I felt quite bored going through it. The third palace was a triumphant comeback with a new writer who I believe wrote the third semester of P5R. If that's true you can tell in how that palace was structured. I loved the narrative and ended up really getting into the focal character of the arc. However, while this third palace was enjoyable, it's not worth going through the first 2 palaces. It's a slog to read and even worse to play.

Gameplay - I was constantly told this game is "just like Persona", but I fail to see the similarities outside of name and presentation. To me, the core beauty of Persona is that things end. You're not going to get all your social links maxed or social stats maxed. Everyone's calendar year is different sparking awesome conversations with different people to see who did what or what you missed out on. I'm probably just naive in thinking that a gacha live service game could adapt this concept. The calendar system in P5X is irrelevant as you will max everything out in time therefore there is no sense of preparation and planning your days or weeks. 99% of game time is just burning your stamina for resources in hopes of better stats or character level up materials. The actual turn based combat itself is fine, but feels like a chore to go through as the majority of fights are brain dead mobs and then bosses with a gimmick built to stall time instead of feeling like a real puzzle to solve. The palaces themselves are incredibly long and arduous constantly testing your patience with uninteresting puzzle design, weak mobs and the aforementioned gimmick bosses. 

Overall - It doesn't feel good to leave a negative review especially for a franchise I love so near and dear to my heart, but Persona 5 The Phantom X is a poor representation of what this series is. Yes, it's free, but you'd be doing yourself a favor and just saving $20 to buy Persona 5 Royal on a sale instead.

Been enjoying the game & all it's content thus far. It's a fairly fun time. Although, something that's not fun is the higher-ups decision not to reduce the jail time of standard characters down from 6 months.

This game does have a standard banner, although any new characters released that are planned for standard must first go through a few weeks where you can pull for premium currency only. Then (unless there's a random re-run) you have to wait 6 months to be able to pull with standard currency. 

This is a bad thing for everyone:
Whales: Will spend all their life savings on all characters regardless, so it doesn't matter for SEGA.
Spenders: Might choose to pull in the first week, but not go for awareness. They now must wait 6 months to pull. They won't bother with awarenesses while premium currency is involved.
F2P: Just won't pull at all for 6 months at all. 

Literally nothing would change here, even if the time period was reduced to 2 months or something. Anyone who really needs the character so bad will have spent... So why annoy the entire playerbase for a supposed monetary gain that's never going to come? Reduce the prison time and make everyone happy. 

I won't be changing this review score until this issue is actually properly addressed by the team.

Most items in the shop are not very good value for their cost. The gameplay is okay; it's turn-based and very P5. So if you like P5, then it's definitely worth playing; however, it will take months to get through the whole game, as main story progress is locked behind account level. with large multi-week gaps. until you get to the max account level, in which case you can rush all the remaining palaces after 3, which sucks because you have to grind for a long time very slowly before all the content opens up, which makes the game feel not worth playing unless you're already committed.

This game is trying too hard to make you purchase to make any significant progress in the game, the gatcha elements are hampering the game.
The standard 4* characters you unlock are mostly underwhelming, while the 5 stars are purposely going to be the hardest to gather to max level.      The actual Palaces in this game are not designed well.   They're level cap controlled to advance half of the time, and they focus far too much on their gimmicks.    The 2nd palace got old in a hurry with all the cameras you needed to activate a door, or resize a block to progress.  They're not so much puzzles, as they are busy work.   And for as large as the palaces are, it's not like you can actually level up in them like you could in P5 as you survived encounters.
There are times some of the story writing brings back elements of a Persona game, but most of them are alternate universe clones to the original P5 cast, and usually not for the better.
If you do the daily quests, you are only really going to be able to focus on getting one thing leveled for one of your thieves daily.   Due to limited stamina,  the stats leveling also goes at a painfully slow crawl since you only get 5 city life points per day.  Want to level up your social links?  Hope you have the patience to level your charm, intelligence, guts, and the others to level 17 so your social links can hit 20 and finish collecting their treasures.   The design is clearly trying to make you  buy progress and spend as much money as possible.   
The release of content is SLOW,  you'll hit the cut off point for the main story, and then wait months before they release a new segment, so there's lots of times you log in and have nothing to do, unless you're slowly trying to level your thieves, weapons, tarot cards, skills ect.  It feels like they tried putting the FU in fun, but not in a witty way.  And a bored player that has nothing to do after checking in will want to leave the game quicker and not return.

Also, the leveling system doesn't feel balanced.   You cap out at level 80, before gaining bonus levels for stat points.   But even by the 3rd palace, you're already required to have your team be close to level 80 across the board if you want to take on the boss.   Even in the first palace when you're low level, you'd be exploring at level 10.  and then a door you need to open to go further has a level 22 guarding it.    Guess how you'll be spending the next week playing?  Grinding just so you can take on that boss.  
This game had a lot of potential to be great, it plays very closely to P5 other than the limited weakness baton pass,  the maps of the towns, the soundtrack were positives.    It looks great on PC, and you can log in from a mobile phone if you link your email account.   But you'll find yourself annoyed and hamstrung regularly because the game is just trying to see how fast you can part with your money.

I was really excited for this game, I had been following it since the early CN betas, and it looked pretty promising to me. The concept of a live service Persona game really excited me, but lately I'm realizing that it doesn't work.

Just to clarify, this review is about the game itself, not the gacha system.
I really don't care that much about the rewards, characters, rates, 110 banner or whatever; give me all the free gems/characters/weapons you want, but my opinion about the game won't change.

So I started playing the game when it came out, and at first I really liked it. Sure, the story was not very good and the combat system is a bit different than the usual Persona, but I found it fun. My first major problem with the game was that there were only two chapters of the main story, but the devs said they would release it faster in order to catch up with CN/KR. Also, since updates are every two weeks, I didn't give it much importance.

The second big issue is with the events, which are either
a) Revisiting P5 palaces (but worse because they're divided in stages)
b) Doing your dailies and getting more rewards than the usual (but no gameplay)
c) Repeating THE SAME battle like 8 times but with different conditions (that change close to nothing)
So the game started to get a bit boring after completing the palaces and mementos, there wasn't much to do apart from these sloppy events and the daily/weekly tasks, which feel too repetitive. There's also the city life part, which includes:
- Social links that require you to grind comically large amounts of social stats xp to continue them.
- Soccer minigame/rhythm minigame (which are absolute slop IMO)
- Not much more... part-time jobs I guess?

And you also have the permanent end-game content...
- Velvet trials... Unfair battle challenges that completely break the usual Persona battle system (by giving the enemies a ton of shields that deny their weaknesses) and require specific characters/elements to complete.
- Metro of desire (roguelike mode): This isn't that bad, but it gets repetitive and feels kinda useless to play when you unlocked everything.

At this point all I did was log in daily for the daily missions and weekly challenges and wait for the story to continue.

And then the moment eventually came. In the 2.0 stream, the devs announced they were going to release the third chapter of the story, which was divided in... 4 stages? Seriously? And they release only the first stage in 2.0?
Well, I guess they'll release the second stage in 2.1... Or at least that's what I thought, but then the 2.1 stream came, and they're releasing the second stage in... 2.3. All that's coming in 2.1 and 2.2 is a summer event. Yes, a summer event. In big September 22nd. 
I've been playing the summer event for a while, and it's the biggest slop I've seen in a very long time. A target shooting minigame, a battle challenge (which is, again, repeating the same battle a bunch of times) and some hangout-like conversations with the characters. Overall, the event feels very unpolished and unnecessary. I kind of feel insulted by this content.

Just when the story was about to get good (or at least that's what everyone who has played in CN/KR says), we're told that we have to wait a month for the second of FOUR stages of one chapter, and all we have until then is a sloppy summer event. But hey, look, characters in swimsuits!
What happened to the "release the story faster to keep up with CN" thing?
So I guess I'll come back when chapter 3 is fully released (which seems is going to be in like 3 months), because I don't really see a reason to keep playing besides the main story.

I know this is a gacha game, and that they usually take some time to release story content (I've played Genshin before), but this is exactly why I think it doesn't suit a Persona game at all. After all, persona games are about making good use of time because it's limited. 
A gacha game where you have unlimited time and you go forever from yesterday to today to tomorrow doesn't follow the franchise's philosophy.

I went in as a huge fan of Persona 5, hoping this spin-off would capture at least a fraction of the magic. Unfortunately, it doesn’t.

The characters feel flat, the story is uninspired, and the gameplay is a watered-down imitation of the original. Instead of being a true continuation or a fresh take, it comes across as a mobile-style cash grab wearing the Persona skin.

Menus are clunky, the flow of combat lacks impact, and the pacing is all over the place. It feels like the heart and soul of Persona 5 were stripped out, leaving only a shallow shadow behind.

If you loved Persona 5, this will just remind you how much better the original was. For me, it was a waste of time.

⭐ 3/10 – A disappointing spin-off with none of the charm of the real thing.
